data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value: Bei dieser Präregistrierung handelt es sich um eine Präregistrierung von einer Hypothese die explorativ an einem Datensatz aufgestellt wurde, und anschließend an einem zweiten Datensatz kreuzvalidiert werden soll.

sample.value: Der erste Datensatz an dem das Modell aufgestellt wurde enthält die Daten von 40 Versuchspersonen. Der zweite Datensatz enthält ebenfalls die Informationen 40 Teilnehmer. Insgesamt werden also die Daten von 80 Versuchspersonen betrachtet.

analyses.value: Um die Hypothese zu überprüfen wird das aufgestellte Regressionsmodell an einem zweiten Datensatz kreuzvalidiert.

dependent.value:
Die abhängige Variable ist der interessierende Depressionsscore.
Dieser soll aus den Variablen "Kritische Lebensereignisse", "Daily Hassles", "Soziale Unterstützung" und einem "Veranlagerungsscore" vorausgesagt werden. Zusätzlich werden jeweils die Interaktionen zwischen den einzelnen Prädiktoren betrachtet und mit in die Analyse aufgenommen. Die Frage ist, welche dieser Variablen oder Interaktionsterme einen signifikanten Beitrag zur Vorhersage leisten können.

hypothesis.value:
Die Variable "kritische Lebensereignisse" kann den Depressionsscore signifikant voraussagen und leistet somit einen bedeutenden Beitrag zur Varianzaufklärung der Regression.

H0: b(EVENTS) = 0
H1: b(EVENTS) ≠ 0

attributes.title: Components and Temporal Dynamics of Sustained Attention in Young Children

summary.value: This preregistration contains an analysis plan of behavioral and eye-tracking data collected in the TrackIt paradigm to measure sustained attention in children ages 3-5. Analyses include testing for effects of condition (relatively salient or non-salient target), age, and trial (over time) on 2 components we believe are part of the process of successful sustained maintenance, as well as a data visualization of the attention measures over age. Some exploratory analyses are also described. Please see attached preregistration document.

registration_responses.summary: This preregistration contains an analysis plan of behavioral and eye-tracking data collected in the TrackIt paradigm to measure sustained attention in children ages 3-5. Analyses include testing for effects of condition (relatively salient or non-salient target), age, and trial (over time) on 2 components we believe are part of the process of successful sustained maintenance, as well as a data visualization of the attention measures over age. Some exploratory analyses are also described. Please see attached preregistration document.

attributes.title: Diabetes as a risk factor for incident peripheral arterial disease in women compared to men: a systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description:
Systematic review and meta-analysis examining the interplay between sex, diabetes, and incident PAD.

Study Authors: 
Alyssa Z. Chase-Vilchez (1), Isaac H.Y. Chan (2), Sanne A.E. Peters (1,3,4), Mark Woodward (1,4,5)
1.	The George Institute for Global Health, University of Oxford, UK
2.	Faculty of Medicine, University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia 
3.	Julius Center for Health Sciences and Primary Care, University Medical Center Utrecht, Utrecht University, Utrecht, the Netherlands
4.	The George Institute for Global Health, University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia
5.	Department of Epidemiology, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD, USA

summary.value:
Previous meta-analyses have suggested that diabetes puts women at a greater disadvantage than men for risk of incident cardiovascular diseases including coronary heart disease, stroke, vascular dementia, and heart failure. In the current meta-analysis, we examined if diabetes also confers a greater excess risk in women compared to men for onset peripheral arterial disease (PAD), another type of cardiovascular disease.

We have attached the study protocol (post data-collection) to this registration. Briefly, PubMed MEDLINE, the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, and Embase were systematically searched for prospective population-based cohort studies. We included studies that provided sex-specific relative risk (RR), and its variability, for incident PAD associated with diabetes. Study authors were contacted in cases where male and female results were not reported separately. We excluded studies that did not adjust at least for age, and in which participants had pre-existing PAD. We included studies across geographic regions and  languages. Random-effects meta-analyses with inverse variance weighting were used to obtain summary sex-specific RRs and the women: men ratio of RRs for PAD. A modified Newcastle-Ottawa scale was used to assess study quality.

registration_responses.summary:
Previous meta-analyses have suggested that diabetes puts women at a greater disadvantage than men for risk of incident cardiovascular diseases including coronary heart disease, stroke, vascular dementia, and heart failure. In the current meta-analysis, we examined if diabetes also confers a greater excess risk in women compared to men for onset peripheral arterial disease (PAD), another type of cardiovascular disease.

We have attached the study protocol (post data-collection) to this registration. Briefly, PubMed MEDLINE, the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, and Embase were systematically searched for prospective population-based cohort studies. We included studies that provided sex-specific relative risk (RR), and its variability, for incident PAD associated with diabetes. Study authors were contacted in cases where male and female results were not reported separately. We excluded studies that did not adjust at least for age, and in which participants had pre-existing PAD. We included studies across geographic regions and  languages. Random-effects meta-analyses with inverse variance weighting were used to obtain summary sex-specific RRs and the women: men ratio of RRs for PAD. A modified Newcastle-Ottawa scale was used to assess study quality.

attributes.title: Calcium imaging & RNA-seq data_Sharma et.al.2019_NCBS TIFR
attributes.description: The raw confocal imaging data, qRT-PCR data, excel files of calcium imaging data, supplementary data and a calcium imaging video file used in "In vitro human stem cell derived cultures to monitor calcium signaling in neuronal development and function" is provided here.

summary.value: The development of the human brain involves multiple cellular processes including cell division, migration, and dendritic growth. These processes are triggered by developmental cues and lead to interactions of neurons and glial cells to derive the final complex organization of the brain. Developmental cues are transduced into cellular processes through the action of multiple intracellular second messengers including calcium. Calcium signals in cells are shaped by large number of proteins and mutations in several of these have been reported in human patients with brain disorders.  However, the manner in which such mutations impact human brain development in vivo remains poorly understood. A key limitation is this regard is the need for a model system in which calcium signaling can be studied in neurons of patients with specific brain disorders. Here we describe a protocol to differentiate human neural stem cells into cortical neuronal networksthat can be maintained as live cultures upto 120 days in a dish. Our protocol generates a 2D in vitro culture that exhibits molecular features of several layers of the human cerebral cortex. Using fluorescence imaging of intracellular calcium levels, we describe the development of neuronal activity as measured by intracellular calcium transientsduring developmentin vitro. These transients were dependent on the activity of voltage gated calcium channelsand were abolished by blocking sodium channel activity. Using transcriptome analysis, we describe the full molecular composition of suchcultures following differentiationin vitro thus offering an insight into the molecular basis of activity. Our approach will facilitate the understanding of calcium signaling defects during cortical neuron development in patients with specific brain disorders and a mechanistic analysis of these defects using genetic manipulations coupled with cell biological and physiological analysis.

registration_responses.summary: The development of the human brain involves multiple cellular processes including cell division, migration, and dendritic growth. These processes are triggered by developmental cues and lead to interactions of neurons and glial cells to derive the final complex organization of the brain. Developmental cues are transduced into cellular processes through the action of multiple intracellular second messengers including calcium. Calcium signals in cells are shaped by large number of proteins and mutations in several of these have been reported in human patients with brain disorders.  However, the manner in which such mutations impact human brain development in vivo remains poorly understood. A key limitation is this regard is the need for a model system in which calcium signaling can be studied in neurons of patients with specific brain disorders. Here we describe a protocol to differentiate human neural stem cells into cortical neuronal networksthat can be maintained as live cultures upto 120 days in a dish. Our protocol generates a 2D in vitro culture that exhibits molecular features of several layers of the human cerebral cortex. Using fluorescence imaging of intracellular calcium levels, we describe the development of neuronal activity as measured by intracellular calcium transientsduring developmentin vitro. These transients were dependent on the activity of voltage gated calcium channelsand were abolished by blocking sodium channel activity. Using transcriptome analysis, we describe the full molecular composition of suchcultures following differentiationin vitro thus offering an insight into the molecular basis of activity. Our approach will facilitate the understanding of calcium signaling defects during cortical neuron development in patients with specific brain disorders and a mechanistic analysis of these defects using genetic manipulations coupled with cell biological and physiological analysis.

attributes.title: Communication Preferences in the Autism Community

q1.value: Communication Preferences in the Autism Community

q3.value:
Communication difficulties are a core diagnostic feature of autism (American Psychiatric Association, 2013). 

In the modern world, there are a myriad of communication options available which are not face to face. Phone calls, email, instant messaging apps and social media have transformed how the entire world talks to each other, and autistic people are included in that seismic shift. What is not known is how these changes affect autistic people's communication, and what their preferences are in different contexts. This is important, both for research and for organisations like local authorities, healthcare, and education providers, if they are to provide accessible services for the autistic community. If we can discover the communication methods that autistic people prefer, we are likely to improve their experiences and interactions, thereby increasing their engagement with research and services. 

We therefore propose to conduct a large-scale, mixed-methods study asking autistic young people and adults about their communication preferences in a range of contexts. In addition we will examine whether a range of factors impact these preferred methods in each situation.

Research Questions

1)	What are the preferred communication methods of autistic people in a range of situations?
2)	Does age, age at diagnosis, camouflaging, and anxiety levels influence preferred communication methods?
3)	What reasons do autistic people give for their communication preferences?

q4.value: All hypotheses are non-directional. H1) Preferences for communication methods will exist; H2) There is a relationship between age and communication preferences; H3) There is a relationship between anxiety and communication preferences; H4) There is a relationship between camouflaging and communication preferences; H5) There is a relationship between age at diagnosis and communication preferences.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: At the time of registration ~100 responses have been collected online. Neither researcher has viewed or downloaded the data.

question.value: This study will recruit autistic adults (aged 16+ years).  The study will be advertised on social media (Twitter, Facebook) and we hope to also advertise through the Autistica Discover Network (an autism research charity network with over 5000 members including autistic people, their families, and professionals who have expressed an interest in taking part in research). Further to these online methods, we will also contact existing connections with charities and support groups across the UK.

q13.value: We will aim to recruit up to 300 autistic people.

q14.value: Our sample size aim is what we believe will be realistic, based upon Dr Sedgewick's previous research using online questionnaire studies and similar recruitment methods.

question.value:
Seven Friedman tests will be conducted to examine whether participants indicate preferred communication methods in each scenario (H1). If a Friedman test indicates that there is a significant difference between preferences, Nemenyi post hoc tests will be run to identify which pairs are different. 

Seven multi-nominal logistic regression models will be built (one for each communication scenario), to test H2-5. For each model, the likelihood of a participant choosing each method as their first choice, relative to all other methods will be the outcome variable. Age, age at diagnosis, camouflaging, and anxiety will be included as predictors.

q20.value: Preference data will be re-coded for the regression analysis to reflect the participant's first choice only.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria.

q22.value: We will verify that each participant has completed the communication preferences ratings, anxiety questionnaire, camouflaging questionnaire, and demographic information about age, and age at diagnosis. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value:
If a participant does not complete the communication preference ratings, they will be excluded from the data-set. 

If a participant completes the communication preferences ratings, but does not report age/age at diagnosis, and/or complete the anxiety questionnaire and camouflaging questionnaire, that participant will be excluded from the regression analysis.

q25.value:
Qualitative Analysis 

After each communication situation is presented, there will be a free response box. This will provide participants with the opportunity to give more detailed and nuanced information about how they communicate in these scenarios. This is important to do, as it is likely that people use multiple forms of communication in each one, so may use them for different purposes, something which the general ranking cannot capture fully and which autistic people in particular are likely to want to expand upon considering the challenges communication can present for them. The questions will be:
“What are the reasons for selecting your first choice?”
“Is there anything more you would like to tell us about how you prefer to communicate in this situation?”.

Qualitative data from the free response boxes will be explored subject to thematic analysis, following the classic six-stage procedure set out in Braun and Clarke (2006) and with reference to their updated guidance on reflexive practice (Braun & Clarke, 2018). Answers will be considered situation by situation, and then any common themes across the whole will be identified and discussed. Both co-Investigators will blind code the written answers, then meet to discuss the congruence of their coding, and consensus themes will be presented in final reports.

attributes.title: Power, dehumanization and decision making
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value: Power induction (high-power vs. less-power) : between-participant, ortho

question10b.value:
Method

Participants
Data from XX participants were used (M = XX, SD = XX), XX were women. All participants were L2 psychology students from the University of Poitiers recruited by the "crédit cours" system. The participants were randomly assigned to one of the 2 conditions of an between-subject plan 2 (Role: Surgeon, Internal).

Material, procedure and variables
The material was translated from Lammers and Stapel, (2011). After filling out a consent form, the participants started a slideshow first presenting the subject of the experiment. A photo of a hospital patient also appeared on this first slide. Then a power induction per scenario was first performed. Half of the participants read a slide which placed them in the role of a senior surgeon (High power condition: N = XX). More specifically, each participant in this group read that he was a senior surgeon, head of department of visceral surgery. In his activity, he was the one who made the decisions regarding the treatment of patients in their department. He was therefore alone in deciding what will be applied, without outside supervision. The rest of the participants read a text placing them in a junior surgeon role (Low power condition: N = XX). The text stated that as a junior surgeon in the service, the participant had not completed his studies. Within his activity, he examined patients and could offer treatments. However, his proposals were supervised by the surgeons and / or the department head. In the end, it was not he who made the decision. For participants trained in senior as well as junior surgeon, they were asked to think about the activities of their role for 1 minute.
The participants then learned about the case of a patient suffering from a deviation of the intestinal wall. This patient, 56 years old and teacher, is admitted to the visceral surgery department with a rare anomaly of the abdominal wall. This defect, a deviation from the wall, can cause long-term problems, but this deviation can be treated and there are two treatment options. Additional information concerning the patient was added, notably concerning his activities during his pre-operative stay: “He reads, watches television, and also spends time on his mobile phone. [He] is walking in the corridors or watching people pass by the window of his room. ” This pseudo-relevant information is intended to add information concerning the target (the patient) without being relevant.

Measures
Participants had to choose between two treatments. The first (treatment A) can be performed under general anesthesia and is therefore painless for the patient who can return home after a few days. The downside of Treatment A is that there is an approximately 20 to 25% chance of complications occurring. If this happens, the operation must be performed again, with an unknown probability of success. As for the second treatment (treatment B), no anesthesia is possible, which makes it painful and unpleasant for the patient who remains conscious during the operation. But treatment B has the great advantage of having guaranteed efficacy and 0% risk of complications. The choice was made on a 9-point scale opposing the two treatments.
Participants were then asked to assign 10 traits to patients, expressing on a 9-point scale whether these traits corresponded from not at all (1) to completely (9) to the patient. Six of these traits (cold, lacks responsiveness, passive, superficial, lacks depth and sensitive) referred to characteristics linked to mechanistic dehumanization (α = .XX). An average dehumanization score was calculated. Four of these traits (funny, smart, sober and generous) referred to a dimension of judgment unrelated to dehumanization (α = .XX)
Finally, the participants answered 4 items (Your opinion has influence, You carry little weight, You have power, You have little control over events) aiming to measure the degree of power that was conferred on them according to their role (α = XX). They gave their level of agreement on a 9-point scale ranging from (1) strongly disagree to (9) completely agree. An average Feeling of Power score was calculated. Note that this manipulation check was not included in the original material of Lammers and Stapel (2011).

question4b.value: Participants are students, 2nd year of Psychology of University of Poitiers

question5b.value: Data from participants will be collected using paper survey and exported to an Excel file. It will be analyzed using R.

question7b.value: Data collection will end when no more slots will be available on "crédit-cours" platform.

question8b.value:
Participants will be excluded if : 
- only using the central response (5) on the Likert-type scale of dehumanization

question1a.value:
Dehumanisation : patient would be dehumanized to a greater extent by high-power participants than less-power participants.

Painfull decision : painfull traitment (traitment B) is more chosen by high-power participants than less-power participants.

question3a.value: 4 items intended to measure the feeling of power are added at the end to check the induction of power by scenario.

question1c.value:
Choice of treatment : 1 item "As a senior / junior surgeon in this service, who ultimately make a decision / even if you can't make any decisions, what do you think is the best option?" and answer on a 9-point scale from 1 (Treatment A) to 9 (Treatment B). 

Dehumanization : 6 items : cold, lacks responsiveness, passive, superficial, lacks depth and sensitive. And answer on a 9-point scale from (1) strongly disagree to (9) completely agree.

Feeling of power : 4 items
"Your opinion has influence", "You carry little weight", "You have power", "You have little control over events", and answer on a 9-point scale from (1) strongly disagree to (9) completely agree.

question2c.value: Regression will be conducted for each measure, on R software.

question3c.value:
DVs :  Dehumanization, Feeling of power
IV : Position of power (low vs high)
Mediator : Choice of treatment

registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Participants will be excluded if : 
- only using the central response (5) on the Likert-type scale of dehumanization

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Explaining away in semantic adaptation: evaluative adjectives norming study

other.value: We ran a pilot study with n=5 per condition (hence some data has already been collected). However, none of the data from this study will be used in the analysis of this experiment.

sample.value: We collect ratings from 40 participants per condition.

analyses.value:
We compute the area under the curve (AUC) for 'terrible', 'bad', 'good', 'amazing'  for each participant. Using these values, we then compute the difference between positive and negative adjectives: ((AUC(good) + AUC(amazing)) - (AUC(bad) + AUC(terrible))). We expect this difference to be greater in the "friend" condition than in the "enemy" condition.

As a second analysis, we compute the expected rating for each adjective by renormalizing each participant's responses for each adjective across the different ratings and computing the dot product of the resulting probability distribution and the corresponding ratings. For each adjective, we compare the expected rating across the "friend" and "enemy" conditions. We expect for all adjectives the expected rating to be higher in the "enemy" condition than in the "friend" condition. Since we are performing multiple comparisons, we perform Bonferroni correction and only consider p-values < 0.01 to be significant.


The exact analysis can be found at

https://github.com/i-loder-matthew/explaining-away/blob/master/experiments/09_evaluative_adj_norming/analysis/analysis.Rmd

outliers.value: We do not perform any exclusions.

dependent.value: We measure production expectations using slider ratings. Participants provide ratings across 5 adjectives (terrible, bad, okay, good, amazing) and a blanket "something else" option by distributing 100 points across these options. Participants provide ratings for 12 trials (2 for each star rating from 1 to 6).

hypothesis.value:
The main question is whether listeners explain away unexpected speaker behavior in the use of evaluative adjectives like 'good' and 'bad' if they are provided with a reason for that behavior (e.g., that they want to be polite or very mean) and therefore do not update their expectations about what a speaker would say in a situation in which there is no reason for unexpected behavior. This study is a norming study for the main experiment and in this study we are testing whether listeners have a priori different expectations about the production of evaluative adjectives if they know that the speaker is evaluating products of a friend or a rival. Participants are asked to complete reviews with a missing evaluative adjective by a fictional bakery reviewer who provided a star rating from 1 to 6. 

We hypothesize that if listeners are told that the reviewer wants to be friendly, that they expect the reviewer to use more positive adjectives (e.g., 'good' and 'amazing'); and when listeners are told that the reviewer wants to be mean, that they expect the reviewer to use more negative adjectives (e.g., 'bad' and 'terrible'). We have no hypotheses about the relationship of the neutral condition to the other two condition, except that we expect the use of adjectives in the neutral condition to fall somewhere in between the other two conditions.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

registration_responses.sample: We collect ratings from 40 participants per condition.
registration_responses.analyses:
We compute the area under the curve (AUC) for 'terrible', 'bad', 'good', 'amazing'  for each participant. Using these values, we then compute the difference between positive and negative adjectives: ((AUC(good) + AUC(amazing)) - (AUC(bad) + AUC(terrible))). We expect this difference to be greater in the "friend" condition than in the "enemy" condition.

As a second analysis, we compute the expected rating for each adjective by renormalizing each participant's responses for each adjective across the different ratings and computing the dot product of the resulting probability distribution and the corresponding ratings. For each adjective, we compare the expected rating across the "friend" and "enemy" conditions. We expect for all adjectives the expected rating to be higher in the "enemy" condition than in the "friend" condition. Since we are performing multiple comparisons, we perform Bonferroni correction and only consider p-values < 0.01 to be significant.


The exact analysis can be found at

https://github.com/i-loder-matthew/explaining-away/blob/master/experiments/09_evaluative_adj_norming/analysis/analysis.Rmd

Participants provide ratings for 12 trials (2 for each star rating from 1 to 6).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The main question is whether listeners explain away unexpected speaker behavior in the use of evaluative adjectives like 'good' and 'bad' if they are provided with a reason for that behavior (e.g., that they want to be polite or very mean) and therefore do not update their expectations about what a speaker would say in a situation in which there is no reason for unexpected behavior. This study is a norming study for the main experiment and in this study we are testing whether listeners have a priori different expectations about the production of evaluative adjectives if they know that the speaker is evaluating products of a friend or a rival. Participants are asked to complete reviews with a missing evaluative adjective by a fictional bakery reviewer who provided a star rating from 1 to 6. 

We hypothesize that if listeners are told that the reviewer wants to be friendly, that they expect the reviewer to use more positive adjectives (e.g., 'good' and 'amazing'); and when listeners are told that the reviewer wants to be mean, that they expect the reviewer to use more negative adjectives (e.g., 'bad' and 'terrible'). We have no hypotheses about the relationship of the neutral condition to the other two condition, except that we expect the use of adjectives in the neutral condition to fall somewhere in between the other two conditions.

attributes.title: Effects of ungulate exclosures on quaking aspen: a meta-analysis

q1.value: Effects of ungulate exclosures on quaking aspen: a meta-analysis

q3.value:
Our research questions are as follows: 
1. How does browsing by ungulates impact aspen regeneration and recruitment?
2. How do ungulate exclosures impact aspen regeneration and recruitment?
To answer these questions, we will conduct a random-effects meta-analysis with hypothesized modifiers included as fixed effects for tests of modifier effects.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Ungulate browsing limits aspen fitness.
Prediction 1:	Fitness traits (growth and recruitment rates etc.) of young aspen will be higher in ungulate exclosures relative to open sites (accessible to ungulates) when effects are averaged across studies.  

Hypothesis 2: As duration of ungulate exclosure increases, the positive effects of exclosure on young aspen fitness traits strengthen.
Prediction 2:	Time since exclosure will be positively correlated with effect size (of exclosure on young aspen fitness traits) across exclosure studies. 

Hypothesis 3: Fitness of young aspen declines as a result of increasing intensity of ungulate browsing.
Prediction 3: 	Larger differences in ungulate browsing between exclosures and open sites is associated with larger differences in fitness traits of young aspen between exclosures and open sites.

Hypothesis 4: Method of measuring fitness of young aspen influences the strength of observed effect of exclosures on fitness of young aspen. This is a non-directional hypothesis.
Prediction 4:	Effect sizes will differ among some or all categories of fitness measures for young aspens. This is a non-directional prediction.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will conduct a random effects meta-analysis with hypothesized modifiers included as fixed effects for tests of modifier effects.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: This study is contingent upon a survey of existing literature focusing on ungulate herbivory on aspen (Populus tremuloides). A refined search protocol will allow us to narrow the scope of our survey to include only studies that incorporate aspen stand exclosures as a mechanism for monitoring recruitment and regeneration with or without the presence of ungulates.

question.value: Our data collection procedure will follow the PRISMA checklist (Moher et al., 2009). We will search Web of Science using a predetermined search protocol (see “Sample Size”), which was developed from a series of pilot searches which allowed us to gain a general understanding the existing literature. We will assess the results of our search based on repeated methodologies, research questions, and procedures between the studies that are of interest to our posed research questions. Specifically, we are seeking studies that incorporate the following: 1. Utilize aspen stand exclosures and control plots to manipulate ungulate browsing; 2. Analyze young aspen fitness traits (measured as size, growth rate, density, survival) in fenced areas designed to exclude ungulates and in reference areas from which ungulates are not excluded. We will not exclude that are missing data for modifier variables. Initial screenings will consist of reading titles and abstracts. Based on this initial screening, any articles that are clearly outside the scope of these criteria will be disregarded. Subsequent full-text screenings will further assess each article for the criteria outlined (1-2) from the abstract screening stage. We will complete a thorough examination of the methods and results sections to extract data. The screening will be completed by two researchers. Any disagreement between the two researchers will be resolved by discussion.

q13.value:
The final sample size will be determined by completing a Web of Science search using specific search terms and subsequent screening. Our search term will be:
(Aspen* or populus tremuloides) (fenc* or exclosure*)

q14.value: We are seeking as many studies as possible to help answer our research question and draw the most robust conclusions possible. Our sample size will be limited only by the extent of our search and the aforementioned criteria.

q15.value: Sample size will be limited by the results of our specified search terms. We will not extend our search beyond the aforementioned search terms nor beyond the Web of Science. We will conduct a search, over the course of a single day, using the terms we have defined to generate a list of all of the studies from which we will derive our analysis.

question.value:
1. We will conduct a random effects meta-analysis with study ID as a random effect and no fixed effects to generate an average Hedge’s D describing the overall average effects of fencing on aspen success.
2. We will conduct a random effects meta-analysis with study ID and all moderators (duration of exclosure, intensity of browsing [as measured by Hedge’s d for the difference in direct evidence of aspen browse inside and outside of exclosure], and type of aspen fitness trait measured [tree density, tree height, recruitment rate, percent canopy cover, or other unanticipated category]) as random effects to calculate heterogeneity and to partition heterogeneity among moderators (Nakagawa and Santos 2012). If any moderator data are missing for any effect sizes, we will conduct this analysis twice, once including only effect sizes with data for all moderators (though excluding any moderators that would require reducing sample size below 60 effect sizes), and another time excluding any moderators lacking data for any effect sizes (i.e., including only moderators with no missing data). 
3. We will conduct a meta-analysis with study ID as a random effect and all moderators as fixed effects to estimate the different Hedge’s D values associated with different values of the moderators.  If any moderator data are missing for any effect sizes, we will conduct this analysis twice, once including only effect sizes with data for all moderators (though excluding any moderators that would require reducing sample size below 60 effect sizes), and another time excluding any moderators lacking data for any effect sizes (i.e., including only moderators with no missing data).
4. If we have excluded any moderator from analysis of fixed effects due to small sample size, we will conduct an analysis with that moderator as the only fixed effect (if n > 19).
5. We will produce a funnel plot (inverse variance vs. Hedge’s D) to assess the hypothesis of publication bias against studies with small sample sizes and small effect sizes or effect sizes suggesting aspen do better outside of exclosures. To test this hypothesis, we will test the prediction that Hedge’s D values will be higher at lower levels of inverse variance of Hedge’s D (higher levels of variance and smaller n) if the hypothesis of publication bias is correct.  
6. We will conduct an Eggar’s regression to further assess the hypothesis of publication bias against studies with small sample sizes and small effect sizes or effect sizes suggesting aspen do better outside of exclosures. If this hypothesis is correct, we expect a slope that differs from zero from this regression. In this regression, we will include the moderators with data available for all effect sizes.

q21.value: We will focus on strength of effect as measured by the meta-analytic average effect size (Hedge’s D). We will adjust our confidence in the observed effect size as a function of the width of 95% confidence limits (narrower confidence limits will increase our confidence in the point estimate). We will avoid dichotomous assessments of statistical significance.

q22.value:
We will exclude studies that do not meet our screening criteria or which do not provide sufficient data to calculate an effect size (after first requesting missing data from authors).
We will exclude from all analyses any moderator with data for <210 effect sizes. We will not exclude effect sizes with missing moderator data.

q23.value: We will contact authors via email requesting missing data. We will email authors twice. If we receive no response within two weeks of the second email, we will not postpone the analysis to wait for the missing data. Data available only in figures and not provided in another form by authors will be extracted from figures using WebPlotDigitizer-4.2.

q24.value: We have no plans to conduct exploratory analyses.

q25.value:
References: 

Nakagawa, S. and E. S. A. Santos. 2012. Methodological issues and advances in biological
Meta-analysis. Ecology and Evolution. 26:1253–1274

attributes.title: Pain rating reduction as a result of mental representation of intimate social support
attributes.description: Testing the hypotheses of pain reduction as an effect of mentally represented social support.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
H1 :
IV photo of romantic partner versus stranger
a. between group design
b. orthogonal

H2 :
IV_1: groups were either in a condition where they were shown pictures of strangers and then of romantic partner
a. within
b. orthogonal

IV_2 : groups subjects same condition but stranger
a. between (condition 1)
b. moderating effect of strangers

question2b.value:
Reported pain ratings in cold pressure task on a scale from 1 to 10 (see Brown et al., 2003) pooled over the 6 ratings given (1 every 10 seconds for a minute).
The task is to plunge their hand into a ice cold bucket of water (0 degree Celcius).

question10b.value:
H1:
Prior to the experiment (during recruitment process) the participants were asked to send the experimentor a photo of their romantic partner. This was then printed out in preparation of the actual experiment.

In the lab, participants were welcomed and given a consent form.
After signing they were explained that they should put their hands in a bucket of ice cold water (around 0 degrees Celsius) and asked to give a rating from 1 (absolutely fine 'as now') to 10 (the most pain they have ever felt). They were asked to give a rating every time they were prompted to. The experimentor asked them every 10 seconds for a minute.

Before starting the clock (hidden to the participants), the experimentor then showed them a picture (either of their romantic partner or a stranger, thus forming the two conditions) and asked to concentrate on them 'as if they were physically present with us here'.

After which they were thanked, given a towel and a chocolate (if desired) and told the rationale for the experiment.

H2:
The same procedure was used for the second hypothesis. However, participants repeated the procedure twice (at different times as to forget about the ratings they reported and avoid repetition effects or habituation), once with a photo of their romantic partner, and once with a picture of a stranger.
For the second group, however, the experiment differed only in that participants were asked to come with a romantic partner or were presented with a stranger (same as in the photo conditions) to be present (holding their other hand) during the cold pressure task.

question4b.value:
Equal number of both genders (see McClelland, L.E., McCubbin, J.A., 2008 for rationale).
All participants must be adults with a romantic partner.

question5b.value: Participants will be recruited on university campus. After consent, the pain rating scores will be given by participants to the experimentor during a cold pressure task.

question6b.value:
H1 :
As the effect sizes in Brown, J.L., Sheffield, D., Leary, M.R., Robinson, M.E. (2003) are usually quite small (Cohen's d usually around .3) the first hypothesis sample calculated with Perugini, M., Gallucci, M., & Costantini, G.'s R script (2018) yielded an estimated sample size of 175.39 (rounded to 176) per group.

H2 :
Using G-power calculator for a mixed between and within group ANOVA design (partner versus strangers & picture versus real presence) for a power of .9 and a sig. of .05 (Cohen's d = .3), then the N per cell was 26.

question7b.value:
H1 : As our power calculations show, we will collect for the first hypothesis around about 352 participants. However, if the Bayes factor (BF) is still insensitive ( 3 > BF >1/3 ) then classical statistical analysis will be terminated and Bayesian estimations only will be used.

H2 : termination of data collection is due when the correct number of participants is obtained.

question8b.value: a) pain ratings consistently high (pain to high for subject to bear)

question9b.value: no such exclusion rates were adapted to the present research.

question1a.value:
H1: Participants who observed a picture of their romantic partner will report lower pain ratings during a cold pressure task than the control group who were shown a picture of a stranger.

H2. Participants who are supported by a physical social support (holding hand) will report lower pain ratings during a cold pressure task than those participants supported by mental activation only. However, participants’ mental activation of a romantic partner will reduce their pain ratings more than those holding the hand of a stranger.

question2a.value:
H1. Primary effect only
H2. We expect the primary effect of actual physical presence compared to mental representation (seeing photo). However, we also expect an interaction effect where seeing the photograph of a romantic partner will reduce pain ratings more than holding the hand of a stranger.

question3a.value:
H1. We expect that participants who observe a picture of their romantic partner will report lower pain ratings than the control group.
H2. We expect that participants pain ratings will be lowest for the group holding their partner’s hand, followed by those seeing a photo of their romantic partner, followed by those holding a stranger’s hand and finally those seeing a picture of a stranger

question1c.value: Two groups depending on if the romantic partner is physically present or not.

question2c.value:
1: A independent sample t-test between two groups.
A Bayesian t-test (independent samples) with Dienes calculator (R script) using the 'room to move' heuristic (Dienes, preprint).

question3c.value:
1: IVs presence or image of romantic partner.
   DV : pain rating scores (pooled over the 6 ratings given over a minute (cf. procedure).

question5c.value:
BF (à la Dienes) of < 1/3 = evidence towards no differences.
BF (à la Dienes) of > 3 = evidence for a difference between conditions

question1c.value:
IV 1 : two groups of people (mixed genders) will either have two pictures (conditions) romantic partner or stranger.
IV 2 : Actual presence of stranger or of partner
DV : difference in pain ratings within groups (partner versus stranger) and then between (picture versus presence)
Interaction : difference of differences

question2c.value:
2: 
a) linear regression analysis using (F-scores) using real or imagined presence and social support type as predictors of pain rating scores (PRS). Mixed model ANOVA (inter - intra)
b) Bayesian t-test of dependent samples between two conditions (BF à la Dienes)
interaction effect : difference of differences (t-test indepedent samples, Dienes BF calculator).
All prior set with the 'room to move' heuristic (Dienes, preprint).

question3c.value:
2: IV1: presence vs. image
    IV2 : stranger vs. romantic partner
    Moderator : social support type (romantic partner vs. stranger
    DV: pain rating scores

question5c.value:
BF (à la Dienes) of < 1/3 = evidence towards no differences.
BF (à la Dienes) of > 3 = evidence for a difference between conditions

The same procedure was used for the second hypothesis. However, participants repeated the procedure twice (at different times as to forget about the ratings they reported and avoid repetition effects or habituation), once with a photo of their romantic partner, and once with a picture of a stranger.
For the second group, however, the experiment differed only in that participants were asked to come with a romantic partner or were presented with a stranger (same as in the photo conditions) to be present (holding their other hand) during the cold pressure task.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Two groups depending on if the romantic partner is physically present or not.

1: A independent sample t-test between two groups.
A Bayesian t-test (independent samples) with Dienes calculator (R script) using the 'room to move' heuristic (Dienes, preprint).

1: IVs presence or image of romantic partner.
   DV : pain rating scores (pooled over the 6 ratings given over a minute (cf. procedure).

BF (à la Dienes) of < 1/3 = evidence towards no differences.
BF (à la Dienes) of > 3 = evidence for a difference between conditions
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest:
Equal number of both genders (see McClelland, L.E., McCubbin, J.A., 2008 for rationale).
All participants must be adults with a romantic partner.
Participants will be recruited on university campus. After consent, the pain rating scores will be given by participants to the experimentor during a cold pressure task.

H1 :
As the effect sizes in Brown, J.L., Sheffield, D., Leary, M.R., Robinson, M.E. (2003) are usually quite small (Cohen's d usually around .3) the first hypothesis sample calculated with Perugini, M., Gallucci, M., & Costantini, G.'s R script (2018) yielded an estimated sample size of 175.39 (rounded to 176) per group.

H2 :
Using G-power calculator for a mixed between and within group ANOVA design (partner versus strangers & picture versus real presence) for a power of .9 and a sig. of .05 (Cohen's d = .3), then the N per cell was 26.

H1 : As our power calculations show, we will collect for the first hypothesis around about 352 participants. However, if the Bayes factor (BF) is still insensitive ( 3 > BF >1/3 ) then classical statistical analysis will be terminated and Bayesian estimations only will be used.

H2 : termination of data collection is due when the correct number of participants is obtained.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques:
IV 1 : two groups of people (mixed genders) will either have two pictures (conditions) romantic partner or stranger.
IV 2 : Actual presence of stranger or of partner
DV : difference in pain ratings within groups (partner versus stranger) and then between (picture versus presence)
Interaction : difference of differences

2: 
a) linear regression analysis using (F-scores) using real or imagined presence and social support type as predictors of pain rating scores (PRS). Mixed model ANOVA (inter - intra)
b) Bayesian t-test of dependent samples between two conditions (BF à la Dienes)
interaction effect : difference of differences (t-test indepedent samples, Dienes BF calculator).
All prior set with the 'room to move' heuristic (Dienes, preprint).

2: IV1: presence vs. image
    IV2 : stranger vs. romantic partner
    Moderator : social support type (romantic partner vs. stranger
    DV: pain rating scores

BF (à la Dienes) of < 1/3 = evidence towards no differences.
BF (à la Dienes) of > 3 = evidence for a difference between conditions
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: a) pain ratings consistently high (pain to high for subject to bear)

attributes.title: A Preference for Error-Inducing Price Complexity

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: Any contrasts between aforementioned conditions but not mentioned as supporting hypotheses may be explored in secondary analyses.

sample.value: ~400 participants will be recruited via MTurk

analyses.value:
We will use proportions tests and logistic regressions with binary outcomes to identify:
1)Whether or not the proportion of individuals choosing a product with a complex disclosure is significantly greater than 50%. 
2) Whether assignment to any condition affects the proportion choosing the complex disclosure.
3) Whether any attitudinal measures are correlated with choices.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who do not answer key dependent variables. 
In robustness checks, we may also exclude participants who do not pass an attention check and/or whose location cannot be verified to be unique.

dependent.value:
Part 1
Seller choice: Participants will make a choice (incentivized with a $.50 bonus) whether to display fees with a complex disclosure, a simple disclosure, or a combo disclosure.

Consumer choice: The same participants will select their display preference for a simple or complex disclosure.

Part 2
Consumer choice: Consumers will be incentivized (with a $.50 bonus) to select the lowest-fee option between two options, one of which is the selection of the seller in Part 1.

conditions.value:
Part 1: 
Higher-v-lower price: Sellers will either be told that their product is cheaper or more expensive than alternatives.
Inform vs. not: Sellers will either be told that complexity obfuscates prices or not.
Seller or consumer first: Participants will answer seller-side questions or consumer-side questions first.

Part 2: 
Consumers will choose between two options, one of which is either a simple or combo disclosure, the other of which is the choice of the seller in Part 1.

hypothesis.value:
H1: More sellers will choose to display fees in more complex than simple ways.

H2: More sellers will choose to display fees in complex ways when their product is more expensive. 

H3: More sellers will choose to display fees in complex ways when their product is more expensive and they’re informed that complexity obfuscates prices, while more sellers with a cheaper product who are told that complexity obfuscates prices will be relatively more likely to choose simpler disclosures. (I.e., Informing sellers of the obfuscating nature of complex price disclosures will amplify effects predicted in H2.) 

H4: When people act as seller first, they’ll be more likely to prefer a simple disclosure as consumers than people who act as consumers first and then sellers.  

H5: Sellers’ selection of complex disclosures will be driven by a desire to obfuscate prices.

H6: Consumers matched with sellers will be more likely to choose higher-fee options when sellers have chosen a complex disclosure. 

H7: Consumers matched with sellers will perceive a high degree of transparency in options with complex disclosures despite sellers having indicated a high degree of desire to obfuscate prices.

registration_responses.name: Seller-side study for complexity project
registration_responses.other: Any contrasts between aforementioned conditions but not mentioned as supporting hypotheses may be explored in secondary analyses.

registration_responses.analyses:
We will use proportions tests and logistic regressions with binary outcomes to identify:
1)Whether or not the proportion of individuals choosing a product with a complex disclosure is significantly greater than 50%. 
2) Whether assignment to any condition affects the proportion choosing the complex disclosure.
3) Whether any attitudinal measures are correlated with choices.

We will exclude participants who do not answer key dependent variables. 
In robustness checks, we may also exclude participants who do not pass an attention check and/or whose location cannot be verified to be unique.

Part 1
Seller choice: Participants will make a choice (incentivized with a $.50 bonus) whether to display fees with a complex disclosure, a simple disclosure, or a combo disclosure.

Consumer choice: The same participants will select their display preference for a simple or complex disclosure.

Part 2
Consumer choice: Consumers will be incentivized (with a $.50 bonus) to select the lowest-fee option between two options, one of which is the selection of the seller in Part 1.

Part 1: 
Higher-v-lower price: Sellers will either be told that their product is cheaper or more expensive than alternatives.
Inform vs. not: Sellers will either be told that complexity obfuscates prices or not.
Seller or consumer first: Participants will answer seller-side questions or consumer-side questions first.

Part 2: 
Consumers will choose between two options, one of which is either a simple or combo disclosure, the other of which is the choice of the seller in Part 1.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
H1: More sellers will choose to display fees in more complex than simple ways.

H2: More sellers will choose to display fees in complex ways when their product is more expensive. 

H3: More sellers will choose to display fees in complex ways when their product is more expensive and they’re informed that complexity obfuscates prices, while more sellers with a cheaper product who are told that complexity obfuscates prices will be relatively more likely to choose simpler disclosures. (I.e., Informing sellers of the obfuscating nature of complex price disclosures will amplify effects predicted in H2.) 

H4: When people act as seller first, they’ll be more likely to prefer a simple disclosure as consumers than people who act as consumers first and then sellers.  

H5: Sellers’ selection of complex disclosures will be driven by a desire to obfuscate prices.

H6: Consumers matched with sellers will be more likely to choose higher-fee options when sellers have chosen a complex disclosure. 

H7: Consumers matched with sellers will perceive a high degree of transparency in options with complex disclosures despite sellers having indicated a high degree of desire to obfuscate prices.
